For example, changes in soil water and fertility with micro-topography can determine the spatial distribution of herbs and shrubs [ 57, 58]. Depression is specifically related to suppressed development of some species [ 41, 59, 60]. Prior to the 1980s, permanent patches of snow were found in depressions where only mosses and lichens grew [ 34]. With global warming, some short-lived herb plants (e.g., C. angustifolia) can survive in depressions [ 61]. The six herb species belong to thermophilic hydro-mesophyte [ 62]. Therefore, we found that herbs typically occurred on semi-sunny slopes.
